ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: VIDCAR: an unsupervised CBVR framework for identifying similar videos with prominent object motion

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: This paper presents VIDeo Content Analysis and Retrieval (VIDCAR), an unsupervised framework for Content-Based Video Retrieval (CBVR) using representation of the dynamics in the spatio-temporal model extracted from video shots. We propose Dynamic Multi Spectro Temporal-Curvature Scale Space (DMST-CSS), an improved feature descriptor for enhancing the performance of CBVR task. Our primary contribution is in representation of the dynamics of the evolution of the MST-CSS surface. Unlike the earlier MST-CSS descriptor [22], which extracts geometric features after the evolving MST-CSS surface converges to a final formation, this DMST-CSS captures the dynamics of the evolution (formation) of the surface and is thus more robust. We have represented the dynamics of MST-CSS surface as a multivariate time series to obtain a DMST-CSS descriptor. A global kernel alignment technique has been adapted to compute a match cost between query and model DMST-CSS descriptor. In our experiments, VIDCAR was shown to have greater precision recall than the competitors on five datasets.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In general, most video search systems (i.e., YouTube, Yahoo videos) work on datasets augmented with user-provided metadata. In some other cases, text surrounding the media or anchor text from links to the media gives indication about the content present in the video shot. Textual information, although valuable, not always provide the correct depiction of the content because of high level of subjectivity and variation in user perception of the content. Modern ways of digital video production and delivery technology have exponentially increased the amount of video data available in digital format. This in turn has increased the need for tools and techniques to be developed at the forefront for video analytics. Over the years, researchers in the field of computer vision and multimedia retrieval have attempted to represent the video content using low-level (bottom up) feature cues or high-level (top down) input from the user, which have given rise to the emerging field of Content-Based Video Retrieval (CBVR). This has a wide range of applications, such as: surveillance, security, entertainment, education, duplicate detection.

A typical CBVR application retrieves video shots from the database (gallery), “similar” to the query video shot provided by the user. The efficiency and effectiveness of any CBVR system depend on the notion of content of that particular system and its representation in the feature database. Hence, representing video based on its content has emerged as an important research area in the field of multimedia retrieval. There are primarily two research issues involved while retrieving similar video shots from the database, namely: (a) effective representation (feature-based) of the video shot and (b) defining a metric to find the similarity between a pair of video shots. In an earlier work [22], MST-CSS was proposed as a video content descriptor for the CBVR task. However, MST-CSS descriptor had some limitations in terms of content representation, application areas and scalability. In [12], we have made an effort to overcome some of them, but the two major aspects which were not addressed include:
Feature descriptors were extracted after the convergence (final formation) of the evolving MST-CSS surface, while ignoring the dynamics of evolution [12, 22].
The earlier proposed techniques were only able to process static camera video shots and not designed to analyze video shots with camera movement.
In this research, we made an attempt to remove both of these limitations and propose VIDeo Content Analysis and Retrieval (VIDCAR), an unsupervised CBVR framework to retrieve videos having prominent object motion. The rest of the paper is organized as follows: in Sect. 2, we discuss some of the works related to our proposed framework. Details of the video content descriptor computation are discussed in Sect. 3. Feature matching and retrieval techniques are discussed in Sect. 4. Details of the experimental setup are given in Sect. 5, while Sect. 6 demonstrates VIDCAR’s retrieval performance, as compared to a few CBVR techniques. Finally, Sect. 7 has the concluding remarks and future scope of work.

Section1.Heading: Related work and motivation
Section1.Para: CBVR has been an area of interest among the many researchers in recent past. Methods published in the literature, similar to our proposed framework, can be broadly grouped into two categories: (i) time series analysis of video shots and (ii) retrieval of similar videos based on its content. We discuss some of the key contributions in both these areas, in the following two subsections.

Section2.Heading: Time series analysis of video shots
Section2.Para: Modeling both spatial and temporal features, extracted from video shots, has been of interest to researchers in the past. In [20], a characterization of the dynamic texture was proposed. A video-based face recognition approach was proposed in [1]. A recognition technique of human gait was proposed in [7]. In [49], a statistical computation technique was proposed for video-based recognition. In [8], a human activity recognition framework was proposed by representing human posture at different time stamp as time series. In [13], geometrical feature of the space-time volume created from the shape contour of the moving foreground blob was modeled as a multivariate time series used for CBVR task. In [35], the authors have extended the traditional similarity search methods on time series data to support a multidimensional data sequence, such as a video. A technique to search similar content in multidimensional data sequence has been reported in. An algorithm to extract time series from video to characterize the type of motion has been discussed in [26]. A framework for finding similar time series with natural relations is proposed in [17]. In [2], a similarity measure for multivariate time series has been proposed using the Euclidean distance based on Vector Auto-Regressive (VAR) models, for human action classification. Full-featured wavelet transforms for similarity search of time series data were proposed in [42]. Bag-of-pattern approach [37], statistical modeling [14], and kernel-based methods [53] were also explored by researchers in the past for modeling time series for different applications. In [39], an unsupervised learning-based object category formation and recognition method for mobile robot vision were proposed from time series images.

Section2.Heading: Content-based video retrieval
Section2.Para: In the recent past, the problem of CBVR has been of prime importance to researchers, both in the pixel and compressed domains [3, 24, 36]. For retrieval tasks, researchers have used motion trajectory-based features as content descriptors in [6, 11, 15, 21]. Statistical features have been reported as a spatio-temporal content descriptor in [38]. The video object-based retrieval technique proposed in [19] segments video objects and represents the color, shape, texture and motion features of video objects. A content-based video copy detection technique is proposed in [43] for large-scale databases. In [52], a spatio-temporal approach for content-based video retrieval was proposed. In one of our earlier work [12], a joint spatio-temporal representation of a video object has been analyzed.

A space-time salient object approach has been reported in [27] for video content representation and retrieval. It proposed a fusion method for motion and spatial saliency integration to detect spatio-temporal salient objects, based on both attention analysis and interest point trajectory tracking. MPEG-7 visual descriptors are used as video content descriptors in [36] for CBVR task using a key frame-based approach. It uses features such as Color Structure Descriptor (CSD), Edge Histogram Descriptor (EHD) to represent the low-level features. Similarity between key frames is calculated using a dynamic-weighted feature similarity calculation. Both [27] and [36] have shown results on datasets [5] of static and moving camera video shots. Very recently in [31], compressed sensing-based algorithms were investigated for video retrieval and a novel similarity measure approach was proposed. An extension of [12] was proposed in [9] to make the CBVR method applicable for moving camera video (MCV) shots.

In all the previous methods published earlier for MST-CSS [22] representation or its variants [9, 12], features have been extracted from the final form of the MST-CSS surface. The dynamics of the evolution of the surface was never explored as a feature descriptor to discriminate between video shots. Indeed, dynamics of surface evolution has been of interest to researchers in many other fields of science and technology [16, 23, 45, 47, 48, 50]. Also, geodesic active contour [10] has been used to segment multiple foreground objects. An introduction to the level-set approaches for various surface evolution methods, which are important in many applications, such as material sciences, image processing and differential geometry is discussed in [29]. In [13], differential geometric properties and time series modeling techniques were combined for CBVR task.

Motivated by the shortcomings of latest CBVR approaches, we propose VIDCAR, an unsupervised CBVR framework (see Fig. 1) that exploits the dynamics of the evolution of the MST-CSS surface. We have introduced a novel feature descriptor Dynamic MST-CSS (DMST-CSS), which captures the dynamics of the evolution of the MST-CSS surface over time. We have experimented with five benchmark video datasets [5, 12, 30, 44, 46], which have video shots with prominent object motion. VIDCAR exhibits superior retrieval performance over a few other existing work on CBVR.

Section2.Heading: Assumptions
Section2.Para: The overall proposed framework works well with the following assumptions: (1) all the videos are shot using a single (static or moving) camera (monocular); (2) a single prominent (salient) moving object is present for the major duration of the video shot without occlusion. We have restricted the types of allowable camera movements to pan, tilt and track. The current version of our proposed framework is not designed for analyzing video shots having camera movements, such as roll, dolly etc. Video shots with arbitrary object posture changes and crowd movement were not considered for analysis.

Section1.Heading: Video content descriptor computation
Section1.Para: The MST-CSS surface construction requires two inputs from a given video shot, they are: (i) silhouettes of the moving foreground object (MFO) from every frame, and (ii) its motion trajectory (for details of the MST-CSS surface construction process, readers are requested to refer [12, 22]). State-of-the-art background subtraction technique proposed in [4] is able to segment the MFO for static camera video (SCV) shots, but failed to do so for MCV shots. We have adapted an iterative refinement-based optimization framework to segment the MFO from an MCV shot.

Using Eq. 6, the parameters of the GMM model are updated by running a few iterations of the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm. The updated model parameters are then used to update the graph edge weights and followed by graph-cut segmentation. This iterative refinement process results in segmentation of the MFO for the entire video sequence. We extract interest points between successive frames, estimate the homography between them to compensate for the camera motion, and then use it to estimate the displacement of the view field due to camera motion. The complete trajectory from the entire video shot is then built by sequentially appending the subsequent displacement vectors estimated from successive pairs of video frames.

Figure 3 shows a few examples of MST-CSS surfaces generated for different categories of video shots. It qualitatively illustrates the discriminating structure of the hilly MST-CSS surface. Careful observation reveals the intra-class similarity (row-wise) and inter-class dissimilarity (column-wise) between the evolved MST-CSS surfaces, which can be attributed to the power and uniqueness of the MST-CSS feature descriptor extracted from a video, to capture the video content and represent it. This has been explained and exploited in our earlier work [12, 22] used for CBVR.

However, in the earlier work, we had overlooked an important aspect in the properties of the evolving surface. We observed that for two similar (i.e., identical category) videos the evolution patterns of the MST-CSS surfaces are also quite similar and very different for dissimilar video shots. Figure 4 shows a few examples of the evolving (at periodic intervals) sequences of MST-CSS surfaces, for four different video shots. Samples in Fig. 4 illustrate that a high degree of inter-class dissimilarity exists among the surface evolution patterns for videos taken from different classes of video shots. We have also observed that, apart from the similarity in the final form (as depicted in the rows of Fig. 3), high intra-class similarity also exists among the evolution patterns of the MST-CSS surfaces in such cases. This similarity in evolution (termed “dynamics” in MST-CSS, henceforth) has been experimentally verified by extracting features from the MST-CSS surface at each step of the evolution and forming a multivariate time series to represent this evolution for CBVR. We term this descriptor as DMST-CSS and prove its effectiveness with extensive experimental study on challenging (i.e., moving camera) video shots (in Sect. 6). Next, we discuss the computation of DMST-CSS feature descriptor in detail.

Section1.Heading: Experimental setup
Section1.Para: We have verified the performance of VIDCAR by extensive experimental study on both static and moving camera video datasets. Details of these two broad categories of datasets are given in the following sub-sections.

Section2.Heading: Moving camera video (MCV) shots
Section2.Para:
We performed experimental evaluation with two benchmark moving camera video (MCV) datasets MCVS [5] and UCF50 [44]. We have experimented with six classes of videos of [44], namely: (i) biking, (ii) horse riding, (iii) car, (iv) rope climbing, (v) running, and (vi) boat. Each of these categories has
$$50$$

$$50$$

videos per class on an average. Videos from both the datasets are of short duration and contain a single prominent object moving in the foreground and the camera movements consist of pan, tilt, track or a combination of them. Accurate segmentation of the MFO across all frames is successfully done by the method discussed in Sect. 3.1.

Section2.Heading: Static camera video (SCV) shots
Section2.Para:

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
In this work, VIDCAR is proposed as an improved CBVR framework. We first create a space-time volume (STV) from the silhouette of the segmented moving foreground blob and its motion trajectory. A series of
$$1$$
1
-D orthogonal processing on the evolving STV gradually yields
$$3$$
3
-D hilly MST-CSS surface. We introduce a novel DMST-CSS feature descriptor to capture the dynamics of this evolution of the MST-CSS surface. We represent this evolution as a multivariate time series feature descriptor, computed at every step of evolution of the MST-CSS surface. Similarity between two such descriptors is measured using a global alignment kernel. Extensive experimental evaluation has been performed on benchmark datasets of both static and moving camera video shots. Results show a significant improvement in retrieval accuracy over a few recent CBVR techniques published in the literature. The entire method is unsupervised in nature. A nice application of DMST-CSS may be explored in future for video database organization and representing multiple moving objects.
